Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: The vast majority of viruses that enter our bodies pass harmlessly through our gastrointestinal tracts or are destroyed by our immune systems.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: However, on rare occasions, an animal virus encounters a human host and begins to replicate itself, executing its entire lifecycle within human cells and expanding one virion into a population of many.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Replication of an animal virus within the body of this first human subject is the key moment in the zoonotic process because it renders possible two things.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: First, the virus will now mutate and evolve under the selective constraints of the human body for the first time, adapting and improving itself for replication in this new host.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Second, high virus titers produced by viral replication mean that spread to a second human is now possible, initiating selection for variants with increased capacity to spread in the human population.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Significant effort has been put into understanding the factors that contribute to the spread of zoonotic viruses through the human population once an animal virus has begun the process described above.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: In the following essay we will argue that, while humans are constantly exposed to animal viruses, those animal viruses with real potential to replicate themselves in a human cell are exceedingly rare.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: We assert that host genetics plays a major role in determining which animal viruses will be able to make copies of themselves in the human body.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: This is because animal viruses that pose the greatest risk to humans will have few genetic barriers to replicating themselves in human cells, thus requiring minimal mutations to make this jump.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: This suggests that far less than 0.1% of the animal viruses in nature have ever caused a known human infection, consistent with other recent estimates .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: If initial viral replication in a human is so incredibly rare and the major bottleneck in this process, then how do we identify which viruses have the potential to break through?

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: In this essay, we discuss the reasons why the vast majority of animal viruses in nature have little or no potential to ever replicate themselves in a human host.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: For instance, HIV is thought to interact with as many as 400 proteins in human T cells .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Animal viruses will replicate in human cells when they can interact with all of the useful host proteins that they need and simultaneously avoid interaction with all of the immunity proteins that will destroy them.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: While an animal virus could be selected for perfecting interactions with human proteins , the conditions for human adaptation will not exist until after viral replication in a human has commenced.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Instead, only "alive-on-arrival" animal viruses, meaning those already able to launch replication cycles upon encountering a human, will have any opportunity to further optimize themselves for the human host.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Stated another way, zoonosis requires that human-compatible viral variants pre-exist in the animal reservoir, arising before these viruses have ever even experienced the selective constraints of the human body.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: The concept here is that animal viruses become increasingly human-adapted through a series of evolutionary steps represented from bottom to top.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis Animal viruses will replicate in human cells when they can interact with all of the useful host proteins that they need and simultaneously avoid interaction with all of the immunity proteins that will destroy them.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Virologists attempt "reverse zoonosis" all the time in the process of establishing animal models for human viruses, with very poor success.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: It is almost always impossible to get human viruses to replicate unaltered in any laboratory animal precisely because most viruses are exquisitely adapted to their natural host.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: In this case, a major obstacle is presented by restriction factors, which are antiviral proteins of the innate immune system that are constitutively expressed, lying in wait in mammalian cells should viruses come along.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: In addition, macaques have a massively expanded MHC class I locus compared to humans, making it extremely difficult for HIV to evade T-cell immunity and establish persistence in these animals .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Likewise, many species have been explored as models for human dengue virus infection, including pigs, monkeys, and rodents .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: This explains one reason why mice are such a popular model organism: when no species can be found that will support the replication of a human virus, mice afford an opportunity to knock out host immunity genes in order to create an animal that will support viral replication.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Additionally, mice can be modified to express human versions of proteins that support virus infection.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: For instance, creation of transgenic mice expressing human versions of the cellular receptors used by poliovirus and hepatitis C viruses leads to enhanced viral infection because these human viruses are not compatible with the mouse orthologs of their receptors .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: In other cases, blocks to human viruses in animals are extreme, and it has been more practical to study related animal viruses in their natural hosts .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: If we assume that the success of reverse zoonosis reflects the success of zoonosis, then decades of work modeling human viruses in animals would suggest that zoonosis is exceedingly difficult to achieve.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Further, human overcrowding has increased the chances that zoonotic viruses will circulate in human populations long enough to be detected.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Yet, still, only 219 viruses have ever been identified in human infections .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: In the following section, we discuss the remarkable ways that the human body defends itself against animal viruses.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Notably, what protects us from animal viruses is often different than what protects us from human viruses.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: The adaptive immune system harbors memory of past infections and ensures a robust and specific response upon secondary exposure.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Adaptive immunity is likely important for limiting human disease caused by animal virus infection.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: However, infection with a new animal virus represents a first exposure, and the adaptive immune system will take several days to activate and mediate an effective response.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: By the time the adaptive immune response kicks in, a swarm of viral variants will exist in the newly infected human, and this swarm may contain variants with improved intracellular replication or even immune escape.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Since this essay especially focuses on the key event of initial viral replication cycles in a first human host, we can at least speculate that adaptive immunity is unlikely to be relevant here.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Only after high virus titers have been reached will an adaptive immune response be mounted.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Nonspecific immune barriers, including skin, mucosa, and chemical defenses , play a key role in blocking animal viruses at portals of entry into the human body.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: However, even if these barriers are penetrated and an animal virus gains access to human cells of its target tissue type, productive replication is still far from guaranteed.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: To launch even a first round of viral replication, animal viruses will need to avoid interaction with a suite of constitutively expressed human innate immunity proteins present inside of human cells, namely restriction factors and pathogen sensors that can activate the interferon response.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: If the animal virus is successfully recognized by any of these human proteins, this will potently block viral replication and will limit even initial rounds of animal virus replication.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: For example, several human restriction factors are efficient at blocking replication of primatederived simian immunodeficiency viruses , and this was important in the emergence of HIV in humans.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: SIV from chimpanzees adapted to overcome the human restriction factors APOBEC3H and Tetherin, giving rise to pandemic HIV-1 group M .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: For this reason, restriction factors and other components of innate immunity seem to be highly relevant to protecting us from zoonotic viruses and less relevant to protecting us from human viruses .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: The complex array of restriction factors and innate immune sensors encoded in the human genome means that most animal viruses would need to escape multiple immunity proteins simultaneously.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: For this reason, animal virus escape from human innate immunity is probably quite rare.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: In addition to avoiding adaptive and innate immune defenses, zoonotic animal viruses must also successfully interact with and recruit tens to hundreds of host proteins that the virus needs in order to replicate itself in human cells .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: If the human version of even one of these essential host factors cannot be recruited by an animal virus because of differences in protein sequence between the human and animal version of that protein, then this, too, can impede viral replication.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: This is probably the main way that immunity to animal viruses differs from immunity to human viruses.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Something as simple as a human transcription factor, mismatched to the animal virus attempting to use it, can be as potent in blocking viral replication as an immunity protein would be.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Avian influenza viruses require a mutation in their PB2 polymerase subunit protein in order to render the avian virus polymerase complex compatible with the human version of ANP32A ).

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Without this mutation, this human transcriptional activator provides a potent block to avian influenza virus replication in humans.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Table 2 shows a collection of human proteins that have been shown to block the replication of animal viruses in human cells.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: While some of them are restriction factors, others are core housekeeping proteins, such as cell-surface receptors, that are not typically thought of as canonical members of the immune system.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Even if these receptors do function in immune signaling, that activity is typically not what is blocking replication of animal viruses.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: We must identify the human proteins that are currently protecting us from each class of animal virus with high zoonotic potential.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Furthermore, the human blocks will be unique for each animal virus of interest.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Then, during the transmission of SIVcpz to humans, protein sequence differences between chimpanzee and human Tetherin, another host restriction factor, also required viral adaptation.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: The virus adapted its vpu gene, which encodes an antagonist of human Tetherin .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Similarly, human APOBEC3H drove adaptive change in the viral vif gene encoding the antagonist for APOBEC3 proteins .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: We do not know whether these vif adaptations were required before the first human infection or afterwards as the virus refined itself for spread in the human population.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: It is possible that these individuals provided a lower adaptive barrier for SIVcpz, giving the virus a foothold in the human population and a chance for the resulting HIV to acquire changes in vif that subsequently enabled it to infect more humans .

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: Dangerous animal viruses are those that require zero or only a few mutations in order to begin replicating themselves in human cells.

Title: How host genetics dictates successful viral zoonosis
Sentence: They are dangerous because these mutational combinations might arise in the animal reservoir or in an intermediate host species, creating alive-on-arrival viral variants that can begin replicating upon encountering a human host.
